title: Q2 Review — Favorite Practical Life Works
description: The child chooses from their favorite practical life activities of the quarter: cooking, sewing, polishing, food preparation, or woodworking. Free choice reinforces mastery and honors the child's interests.
instructions:
1. 'This is our last week of the quarter! You have learned SO many practical life skills. Today you choose your FAVORITE to do again.'
2. Present the choices: 'You could make trail mix or fruit salad, do embroidery, sand wood, hammer nails, polish metal, or arrange flowers.'
3. 'Which one is your favorite? That is what we will do today!'
4. Child sets up the chosen activity independently.
5. Observe: does the child remember all steps without prompting?
6. Note areas of confidence and areas that still need practice.
7. Celebrate: 'Look at how much you can do now that you could not do at the beginning of the quarter!'
materials_needed: Materials for child's chosen activity (cooking supplies, sewing supplies, woodworking supplies, polishing kit, flower arranging supplies)

slides.heading: Q2 Review
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! This is our special review time for all the super cool things you learned to do with your hands this quarter. We're going to pick your very, very favorite thing to do again!

slides.setup_instructions: Have 3-4 practical life activities available and prepared. Let the child choose which to do.
slides.mascot_explanation: See this tray? We use it to keep all our special tools nice and tidy. You get to choose which fun activity you want to do today, and then we'll get all the special things ready together.

slides.text: 'This quarter you learned to cook, sew on fabric, sand wood, hammer nails, and so much more. Today is YOUR choice — which work do you want to do?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Remember how you learned to do so many amazing things, like helping in the kitchen, making pretty things with needles, or building with wood? Today, you get to pick just one of those things that you loved the most to do again.

slides.text: 'Get your materials ready by yourself. Remember all the steps? Show me what you know!' Observe but do not direct unless asked.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to show me how much you remember! You are going to get all the things you need for your special job all by yourself. I know you can do it!

slides.text: If the child finishes quickly: 'Would you like to try a second activity? Or do the same one again to make it even better?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you finished so fast! That was amazing! Would you like to do that super fun job one more time, or pick a different one to try?

slides.text: 'When you are finished, put everything back exactly where it belongs. Leave the workspace clean and ready for next time.'
slides.mascot_explanation: When you are all done with your super job, it's time to put everything back just where it belongs, like a good helper. We want to leave our special space all clean and tidy for next time.

slides.prompt: Do your chosen practical life work from start to finish, completely independently. Take your time and enjoy the process.
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, it's time to do your favorite thing! Take your time and have lots of fun doing it all by yourself. You've got this!

slides.text: 'You did that entirely on your own! Think about when you first started — you have grown so much. I am proud of your independence!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child independently set up, complete, and clean up their chosen practical life activity with minimal or no assistance?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it all by yourself! That's so amazing! Remember when we first started? You have learned so much and become so independent, and I am super proud of you!

parent_notes: Free choice is a fundamental Montessori principle — the child who chooses their own work is intrinsically motivated and more focused. Use this lesson as an informal assessment: observe which activities the child gravitates toward (these are strengths to build on) and which they avoid (these may need more practice or a different approach). Resist the urge to direct — this is the child's time to demonstrate independence. If they struggle with a step they previously mastered, offer a gentle reminder rather than taking over. The end-of-quarter review celebrates growth and builds confidence. Consider taking photographs or videos of the child working to add to their portfolio.

title: Q2 Language Review — Phonogram Assessment
description: Informal assessment of all phonograms learned in Q2: sh, ch, th, ai, oa, ee, oo. The child reads phonogram cards, builds words, and reads sentences to demonstrate mastery.
instructions:
1. 'Let us see how many phonograms you remember! I will show you a card, and you tell me the sound.'
2. Flash all 7 phonogram cards: sh, ch, th, ai, oa, ee, oo. Record which ones the child knows instantly.
3. For any the child hesitates on, review briefly.
4. Word reading: present 14 words (2 per phonogram). Child reads each.
5. Sentence reading: present 5 sentences containing phonogram words and puzzle words.
6. 'Now build a word for each phonogram with the moveable alphabet.'
7. Celebrate strengths. Note areas for Q3 reinforcement.
materials_needed: Phonogram cards (sh, ch, th, ai, oa, ee, oo)

slides.heading: Q2 Language Review
slides.mascot_explanation: Look, this is the name of our game today! We're going to play a fun game to see all the special sounds you learned in school. It's like a treasure hunt for all the sounds in words!

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare phonogram cards, word cards, and sentence strips. Have a record sheet to note the child's responses (for parent use, not shown to child).
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these fun things we get to use! We have special cards with sounds on them, and other cards with words and sentences. We also have little letter tiles to build words. Ask your grown-up to help you get these ready for our game!

slides.text: 'You have learned so many phonograms this quarter! Let us play a game — I show you a card, you tell me the sound. Ready?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this is where our game starts! You are so smart, and you learned so many sounds. I'm going to show you some special cards, and you tell me the sound each one makes. Are you ready to show me how clever you are?

slides.text: Flash cards one at a time: sh, ch, th, ai, oa, ee, oo. Note instant recognition vs. hesitation. For any missed: 'Remember, this one says...' Quick review.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to look at the sound cards one by one. When you see a card, tell me the sound it makes. If you need a little help, that's okay! We can whisper the sound together.

slides.text: 'Excellent! Now read these words.' Present: ship, chin, that, rain, coat, tree, moon, fish, chop, three, tail, road, feet, spoon. Child reads each.
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a great job with the sounds! Now, let's read some words. I'll show you a word, and you tell me what it says. You are going to read them so well!

slides.text: 'Now read these sentences!' Present strips like: 'The sheep is in the rain.' 'A boat is on the sea.' 'The bee sat in the tree.'
slides.mascot_explanation: You're reading so fast and so well! Now, let's read some little stories. These are sentences, and they have words with the special sounds we learned. Read them just like you read the words.

slides.prompt: Build one word for each phonogram using the moveable alphabet: a 'sh' word, a 'ch' word, a 'th' word, an 'ai' word, an 'oa' word, an 'ee' word, and an 'oo' word.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where you get to be a word builder! We have all these letter tiles, and we're going to use them to build words that have our special sounds. Let's make a word with 'sh', then a word with 'ch', and so on. You can do it!

slides.text: 'You know SEVEN phonograms! That is amazing. These phonograms unlock hundreds of words. You are becoming a strong reader!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify all 7 phonograms by sound, read words containing them, and build at least 5 of 7 phonogram words independently?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay! You finished our game! You know SEVEN special sounds and you read so many words and sentences. That's super amazing, and you are becoming such a big, strong reader!

parent_notes: This is an informal assessment, not a test. Keep the tone light and celebratory. Use the record sheet for your own reference to plan Q3 review. If the child knows 5 out of 7 phonograms instantly, that is excellent progress. The ones they hesitate on simply need more exposure — not drilling. Note which words the child reads fluently vs. which require sounding out; both are acceptable, but fluent recognition shows deeper mastery. The sentence reading is the most authentic assessment: can the child put it all together — phonics, phonograms, puzzle words — to read connected text? If they can read even simple sentences independently, they have made remarkable progress. Celebrate this milestone.

title: Q2 Math Review — Golden Beads and Stamp Game Operations
description: Review of Q2 math concepts: golden bead formation, stamp game addition and subtraction, and introduction to multiplication. The child revisits each operation with their preferred material.
instructions:
1. 'This week we review everything we learned in math this quarter. Let us start with the basics!'
2. 'Build the number 3,456 with the stamp game.' Child builds.
3. 'Now let us add: 1,234 + 2,341.' Child works through with stamps.
4. 'Subtract: 4,567 - 2,345.' Child works through with exchange as needed.
5. 'Multiply: 123 taken 3 times.' Child works through.
6. 'Which operation is your favorite? Why?'
7. Child chooses one more problem of their favorite operation.

slides.heading: Q2 Math Review
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! We get to play a math game and practice all the cool things we learned this school year. It's like a super math review party!

slides.setup_instructions: Set up the stamp game. Prepare 2-3 problems for each operation: addition, subtraction, multiplication. Have golden beads available if the child prefers them.
slides.mascot_explanation: To get ready for our math fun, we need some special tools! We have our stamp game with little squares for numbers, a mat to keep things tidy, and some cards with math problems. If you like, we can also use the golden beads, which are like sparkly number treasures! Ask a grown-up to help you find these to play with.

slides.text: 'This quarter you learned to add, subtract, AND multiply with the stamp game! Let us practice each one. Which would you like to start with?'
slides.mascot_explanation: This quarter we learned SO many new math tricks with our stamp game! We learned how to add, subtract, and even multiply, which is like adding really fast. Now, we get to practice them all again. Which one do you want to play with first?

slides.text: 'First, let us build a number. Make 3,456 with stamps.' Check accuracy. 'Perfect! You know your place values: thousands, hundreds, tens, units.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, first we get to build a big number with our special stamps! We need to make the number 3,456. Remember, the stamps help us see how many thousands, hundreds, tens, and ones there are. You're doing such a great job showing me you know all the places!

slides.text: 'Now ADDITION with exchange: 1,234 + 2,341.' Child builds both numbers and combines, exchanging as needed.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time for some addition magic! We're going to put the number 1,234 and the number 2,341 together. Watch how we can swap groups of stamps if we have too many in one spot, like turning ten little ones into one ten-stamp. You can do it!

slides.text: 'SUBTRACTION with exchange: 4,567 - 2,345.' Child builds the first number and subtracts, exchanging when a category does not have enough.
slides.mascot_explanation: Next, we get to take some numbers away – it’s subtraction time! We start with 4,567 and then we need to carefully take away 2,345. If we don't have enough stamps in one spot, we can borrow from the next bigger spot, just like sharing toys.

slides.prompt: Now MULTIPLICATION: 123 taken 3 times. Build 3 rows of 123 and combine. Then choose your favorite operation and solve one more problem!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for a super cool trick: multiplication! We're going to take the number 123 and do it 3 times. Imagine making three lines of 123 stamps and then seeing how many we have altogether! After this, tell me which math game was your favorite, and we can play one more problem just for fun!

slides.text: 'You can add, subtract, and multiply with the stamp game. These are the same operations adults use — you are doing REAL math!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child perform addition, subtraction, and multiplication with the stamp game, exchanging correctly?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, you did it! You showed me how to add, subtract, and multiply using the stamp game. These are the same grown-up math skills that grown-ups use every single day. You are doing real math, and you are so good at it!

parent_notes: This review covers the major Q2 math milestones. The child should be able to: build any 4-digit number with stamps, add with exchange, subtract with exchange, and multiply (build same number multiple times and combine). If the child struggles with any operation, note it for Q3 reinforcement but do not reteach in this session — the goal is confident practice, not remediation. Offering choice ('which operation first?') honors the child's agency. Some children strongly prefer one operation over others — this is natural. The fact that a 5-year-old can add 4-digit numbers with exchange is remarkable; help them appreciate their accomplishment.

title: Q2 Geography Review — Puzzle Maps and Continents
description: Review of all geography work from Q2: world continents, North America, South America, and Europe. The child demonstrates their knowledge of continents and countries learned this quarter.
instructions:
1. Start with the globe: 'Point to each continent and name it.'
2. World puzzle map: child assembles and names all 7 continents.
3. 'Which continents did we study closely this quarter?' North America, South America, Europe.
4. Europe puzzle map: child places and names as many countries as they can.
5. 'Tell me one fact about each country you remember.'
6. 'Which continent or country was your favorite to learn about?'
7. Look ahead: 'Next quarter we will explore Africa and Asia!'

slides.heading: Q2 Geography Review
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! It says we're going to do a super fun review of all the cool places we learned about, like all the big lands called continents and the countries inside them! We get to remember all the amazing geography adventures we've had.

slides.setup_instructions: Have the globe and all studied puzzle maps accessible. Lay out flag cards for matching.
slides.mascot_explanation: We need some special toys for our geography journey! We have a round globe that looks like our whole world, and some big puzzle maps of the world and Europe. We also have pretty flag cards to help us remember each country. Let's get them all ready!

slides.text: 'Let us travel the world today! Start with our globe. Can you point to and name all seven continents?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Our first stop is the globe! Can you find all the big lands called continents and say their names out loud for me? We're going to pretend we're flying all around the world and pointing to each one.

slides.text: World puzzle map: 'Put the continents together! North America, South America, Europe, Africa, Asia, Australia, Antarctica.' Child assembles.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's put the world back together like a big puzzle! We'll find all the pieces for North America, South America, Europe, Africa, Asia, Australia, and Antarctica and put them right where they belong. You can do it!

slides.text: 'This quarter we zoomed into Europe. Show me the countries you remember!' Child places pieces and names them: Italy, France, Spain, UK, Germany, Sweden, Greece, Russia.
slides.mascot_explanation: This quarter, we learned all about Europe! Let's see if you can remember all the countries we studied, like Italy and France, and put them on the Europe puzzle map. Tell me their names as you find them!

slides.text: 'Tell me something you remember about each country!' Italy looks like a boot, Sweden has meatballs, Greece started the Olympics, Russia is the biggest country...
slides.mascot_explanation: That's amazing! Now, can you tell me something fun you remember about each country, like how Italy looks like a boot? We'll share all the cool facts we learned about these places.

slides.prompt: Match flag cards to their countries on the map. Then tell me: which was your favorite continent or country? What would you like to learn next?
slides.mascot_explanation: Time for a fun game! Let's match the little flag cards to the countries on our puzzle map. Then, you can tell me your very favorite continent or country we learned about and what you're excited to learn next!

slides.text: 'You have traveled the world through maps! You know seven continents and many countries. Next quarter: Africa and Asia await!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name all 7 continents, assemble the world map, and name at least 6 European countries with a cultural fact?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay! You did such a wonderful job reviewing all the continents and countries! You're a super geographer, and you remembered so many amazing things. Next time, we'll explore even more exciting places like Africa and Asia!

parent_notes: Geography review should feel like a grand tour, not a quiz. The child has accumulated impressive knowledge: continents, countries, flags, and cultural facts. As they name countries and share facts, you will see which information stuck and which faded — this guides Q3 planning. If the child has forgotten some countries, simply remind them casually. The preview of Africa and Asia creates excitement for next quarter. Consider creating a passport-style booklet where the child stamps each continent they have studied — this makes the learning journey visible and motivating. Display the child's best map work as part of the Q2 celebration.

title: Read-Aloud: A Seed Is Sleepy by Dianna Hutts Aston
description: Reading 'A Seed Is Sleepy' by Dianna Hutts Aston, a gorgeously illustrated nonfiction book exploring the many fascinating qualities of seeds.
instructions:
1. Show the cover. 'What do you know about seeds? What do they do?'
2. Read aloud slowly — each page spread deserves time for the stunning illustrations.
3. Pause at each descriptor: 'A seed is sleepy... adventurous... creative...'
4. Connect to real seeds: show different seeds if available.
5. Discuss: 'How is a seed like a baby? What does it need to wake up?'
6. Marvel at the diversity of seeds in the world.
materials_needed: A Seed Is Sleepy by Dianna Hutts Aston
Optional: collection of different seeds to examine

slides.heading: Read-Aloud
slides.subheading: A Seed Is Sleepy by Dianna Hutts Aston
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this book cover! It's called "A Seed Is Sleepy." We're going to read a story all about seeds and what they do. Isn't that exciting?

items: Optional: assorted seeds for hands-on exploration
slides.setup_instructions: Have the book and any seed samples ready.
slides.mascot_explanation: We need our special book, "A Seed Is Sleepy," to start our adventure. If you have some different kinds of seeds, like tiny ones or big ones, we can look at those too. Can you get them ready with a grown-up?

slides.text: Cover: 'This book says a seed is sleepy. What do you think that means? Can seeds really sleep?'
slides.mascot_explanation: This book says seeds are sleepy. What do you think that means? Can seeds really take a nap like you do? Let's find out together!

slides.text: Read slowly and with wonder. Sylvia Long's watercolor illustrations are breathtaking — give time to explore each page.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to read our story very slowly. Look at all the pretty pictures on each page! They show us so many cool things about seeds.

slides.text: Discuss: 'What surprised you about seeds? Which seed was your favorite? How are seeds adventurous?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, seeds can be so many things! Were you surprised by anything you learned? Which seed did you like the best, and how do you think seeds are adventurous?

slides.prompt: Examine real seeds if available. Sort them by size, shape, or color. Draw your favorite seed and write one word to describe it.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's play with some real seeds now! We can look at them up close, sort them into groups by how they look, and then draw your favorite one. What word should we use to tell everyone about it?

slides.text: 'Seeds are tiny, but they hold everything needed to become a whole plant. That's amazing!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child describe at least two interesting things about seeds?
slides.mascot_explanation: Isn't it amazing that such tiny seeds can grow into big plants? You learned so many cool things about seeds today, like how they can be sleepy and adventurous! Great job exploring with me!

parent_notes: This gorgeous nonfiction book is perfect for the Montessori botany curriculum. Dianna Hutts Aston's poetic text paired with Sylvia Long's illustrations make science feel magical. The book introduces dormancy, dispersal, germination, and seed diversity. Consider starting a seed collection or germination observation alongside this reading.

title: Q2 Sensorial Review — Free Choice of Favorite Materials
description: The child chooses from all sensorial materials explored this quarter: geometric solids, geometric cabinet, constructive triangles, trinomial cube, and color grading. Free choice reveals preferences and areas of deep engagement.
instructions:
1. 'This quarter you worked with many sensorial materials. Today you choose your favorites!'
2. Available choices: geometric solids, geometric cabinet drawers, constructive triangles, trinomial cube, color tablets grading.
3. Child selects and works independently.
4. Observe: which material does the child choose? How confident are they?
5. If time allows, offer a second choice.
6. 'What was your favorite sensorial work this quarter? Why?'
7. Note observations for Q3 planning.

slides.heading: Q2 Sensorial Review
slides.mascot_explanation: Look! We're going to play with some special learning toys today, and you get to pick which ones! It's like a surprise party for your brain!

slides.setup_instructions: Set up 3-4 sensorial activities on separate mats so the child can see their options and choose freely.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these wonderful things we can play with! We have cool shapes, colorful squares, and even special blocks. Can you see the different things we can choose from?

slides.text: 'Look at all the sensorial work you have done this quarter! Today you get to choose. Which materials call to you? Take your time deciding.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Remember all the fun things we learned with our special toys this year? Today is your chance to pick your very favorite ones to play with again! Take a good look and see which ones you really want to play with.

slides.text: 'Set up your chosen work. Remember: carry the material carefully, work on the mat, and return it when you are finished.'
slides.mascot_explanation: When you pick a toy, we need to be super careful with it. Let's put it on our special mat and play nicely, just like we always do. And when we're all done, we put it back neatly.

slides.text: Observe silently. Let the child work without interruption. Only assist if directly asked.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time for you to play! You can touch and explore all by yourself. If you need a little help, just let me know, but I bet you can do it!

slides.text: 'Would you like to choose a second material? Or continue with this one?' Honor the child's choice.
slides.mascot_explanation: Would you like to pick another fun toy to play with, or do you want to keep playing with the one you have? Whatever you choose is perfect!

slides.prompt: Work with your chosen material(s) for as long as you like. When you finish, put everything back in its place. Then tell me: what was your favorite sensorial work this quarter?
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's play with your favorite toy for a little while! When you're finished, we can talk about which one was the most super-duper fun this whole time.

slides.text: 'Your hands and eyes have learned to notice shape, color, size, and pattern. These sensorial skills help you in everything you do!'
slides.mastery_check: Does the child work confidently and independently with their chosen material? Can they articulate why they enjoy it?
slides.mascot_explanation: You are so good at noticing all the special things about shapes and colors! All this playing helps your brain grow strong for everything you do!

parent_notes: Free choice during review week is not idle time — it is deeply informative. The materials a child chooses reveal their natural interests and learning style. A child who gravitates toward the trinomial cube may be a spatial thinker. One who chooses color tablets may be visually oriented. One who returns to geometric solids may enjoy tactile learning. All are valid and valuable. The ability to choose, sustain work independently, and clean up is itself a major developmental achievement. If the child wants to combine materials in unexpected ways (using color tablets to sort geometric solids by color, for example), allow this creativity — it shows advanced thinking.

title: Independent Reading Practice
description: The child spends extended time reading independently from a selection of decodable books. This sustained reading practice builds fluency, stamina, and confidence.
instructions:
1. 'Today is special reading time. You get to read on your own, just like big readers do!'
2. Set up a cozy reading corner with 5-6 decodable books at the child's level.
3. 'Choose a book, sit comfortably, and read. If you get stuck on a word, try to sound it out. If you still need help, come ask me.'
4. Child reads independently for 10-15 minutes.
5. After reading: 'Tell me about the book you read. What happened?'
6. 'Would you like to read another one?'
7. Celebrate the sustained reading: 'You read for 15 minutes all by yourself!'
materials_needed: 5-6 decodable readers at the child's level
Comfortable reading spot (pillow, bean bag, special chair)
Timer (optional, do not show the child)

slides.heading: Independent Reading
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this! It says "Independent Reading" and "Reading Time." That means it's your special time to be a super reader all by yourself!

slides.setup_instructions: Create an inviting reading space. Select books the child can read with 90% or higher accuracy. Variety in topics is ideal.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these books! These are special books just for you to practice your reading. We also need a cozy spot to sit, like a comfy chair or a soft rug. You can ask a grown-up to help you pick out the books and find your special reading spot.

slides.text: 'Today you are a reader reading all on your own! Pick any book from this selection. Find a comfy spot. And read!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is your first reading job! You get to pick any book you want from the ones we chose. Then, find your comfy spot and open the book to read all by yourself, just like a big kid!

slides.text: 'If you finish one book, you can read another. Or you can reread a favorite — rereading makes you a smoother reader.'
slides.mascot_explanation: When you finish one book, you can pick another one to read! Or, if you really loved a book, you can read it again. Reading the same book helps you become an even faster and better reader!

slides.text: Step back and let the child read. Be available but not hovering. A child reading independently is doing important, deep work.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, now it's time for you to be a super reader! I'm going to sit over here quietly while you pick a book and read. You can do it! I'm here if you need me, but I know you can read on your own.

slides.text: After reading time: 'Tell me about what you read. What was your favorite part? Was there anything tricky?'
slides.mascot_explanation: All done reading? That was wonderful! Now, can you tell me a little bit about the book you just read? What was your favorite part, or was there anything that was a little hard to read?

slides.prompt: Read as many books as you want! After each one, think about: who was in the story? What happened? Did you like it?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You read all by yourself for a long time! Real readers get to choose their own stories and read them all alone, and you were a real reader today!

slides.text: 'You read ALL BY YOURSELF for a long time! Real readers choose their own books and read independently — and that is exactly what you did today.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child sustain independent reading for 10-15 minutes, decode most words, and retell what they read?
slides.mascot_explanation: You were such a great reader today! You picked your own books and read them all by yourself for a long, long time. That's how super readers practice!

parent_notes: Sustained independent reading is a milestone that signals the transition from 'learning to read' to 'reading to learn.' The child's reading stamina will vary — some can sustain 15 minutes, others may need to start with 5 and build. Choose books at the child's INDEPENDENT level (they can read 90%+ of words without help), not their instructional level (where they need support). This ensures a positive, fluent experience. A reading log where the child records or stamps each book they have read provides visible progress and motivation. Some children want to read to a stuffed animal or pet — this is wonderful practice. Resist the urge to correct every mistake during independent reading; it interrupts the flow and joy.

title: Q2 Fraction Review — All Fraction Concepts
description: Comprehensive review of fraction concepts: naming fractions from halves through tenths, comparing sizes, finding equivalences, and connecting fractions to real-life situations.
instructions:
1. 'Let us review everything we know about fractions!'
2. Lay out all fraction circles. Child names each: whole, halves, thirds, fourths, fifths, tenths.
3. 'Show me one half. Show me one fourth. Which is bigger?' Child demonstrates.
4. Equivalence check: 'How many fourths equal one half? How many tenths equal one half?'
5. 'How many thirds make a whole? How many fifths?'
6. Real-life connection: 'If we have 8 crackers and 4 people, what fraction does each person get?'
7. Child creates a fraction poster showing what they know.

slides.heading: Q2 Fraction Review
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! It says "Q2 Fraction Review" and "Everything About Fractions." That means we get to remember all the super cool things we learned about fractions this school year! Let's have some fun remembering them all.

slides.setup_instructions: Lay out all fraction circles and labels. Have poster paper ready for the creative activity.
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, we get to gather our special fraction tools! We have these round pieces that show different fractions, and little cards to name them. We also need a big piece of paper and some colorful crayons and markers to make a beautiful poster! Ask your grown-up to help you find these things so we can get started.

slides.text: 'Fractions were brand new this quarter and now you know so much! Let us show what you have learned. Name each fraction circle as I hold it up.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's look at our fraction circles! We're going to name each one together. When I show you a piece, you tell me what it is – like a whole circle, or maybe it's cut into two equal parts, which we call halves! You're going to be so good at naming them.

slides.text: 'Quick comparisons! Which is bigger: 1/3 or 1/4? Show me with the pieces. Which is smaller: 1/2 or 1/5? Remember: MORE pieces means SMALLER pieces!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's play a little guessing game with our fraction pieces! We'll see which piece is bigger. Is one-third bigger or one-fourth bigger? Show me with the pieces! And which is smaller, one-half or one-fifth? Remember, the more pieces there are, the smaller each piece gets!

slides.text: 'Equivalence check: place 2 fourths next to 1 half. Equal! How many tenths equal one half? Five! You discovered that yourself!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is like a puzzle! We're going to see how different fraction pieces fit together. Let's put two of the fourths pieces next to the one-half piece. See? They're the same size! Now, can you find out how many tiny tenths pieces make one-half? You're so smart!

slides.text: 'Real life fractions: if we cut a pizza into 4 slices and you eat 1, you ate 1/4 of the pizza. If the pizza had 8 slices and you ate 2, that is 2/8 — also 1/4!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Fractions are like sharing! Imagine we have a yummy pizza cut into 4 slices, and you eat 1 slice. That means you ate one-fourth of the pizza! If the pizza had 8 slices and you ate 2, that's still the same amount, just like one-fourth!

slides.prompt: Create a FRACTION POSTER! Draw circles divided into halves, thirds, fourths, fifths, and tenths. Color them. Label each fraction. Add real-life fraction examples!
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to make our amazing fraction poster! We'll draw circles and divide them into all the different fractions we know. Then we can color them in and write their names, and even draw pictures of real things that are fractions, like a cut apple! You get to be the artist!

slides.text: 'Look at your fraction poster — you know so much about fractions! This is knowledge you will use for the rest of your life. Hang it on the wall!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name fractions through tenths, compare sizes, find at least 2 equivalences, and connect fractions to real life?
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this incredible poster you made! You remembered how to name all the fractions and even how they compare. You are a fraction superstar and will use this smart brain power for a long, long time. Let's hang this up so everyone can see how much you know!

parent_notes: The fraction poster serves as both an assessment and a celebration. The child creates a visual record of their fraction knowledge that can be displayed and referenced. Fractions were introduced only 2 weeks ago — do not expect perfection. If the child confidently names halves, thirds, and fourths, compares sizes, and finds one equivalence (2/4 = 1/2), that is excellent. Fifths and tenths may need more practice in Q3. The real-life connection is the most important check: can the child see fractions in the world around them? If yes, the foundation is strong. Fractions will be revisited and extended throughout elementary — this is just the beginning of a long journey.

title: Q2 Science Review — Animal Kingdom Classification
description: Review of Q2 science concepts: vertebrates vs. invertebrates, the five vertebrate classes, and detailed knowledge of birds and fish. The child sorts animals and shares what they learned.
instructions:
1. 'Let us review the Animal Kingdom! First: what is the big division?'
2. 'Vertebrates have ___. Invertebrates do not have ___.' Child fills in: backbone.
3. 'Name the five classes of vertebrates.' Child names: fish, amphibians, reptiles, birds, mammals.
4. Lay out animal picture cards. Child sorts into: vertebrate/invertebrate first, then into the 5 classes.
5. 'Tell me about birds — what makes them special?' (Feathers, beaks adapted to food.)
6. 'Tell me about fish — what makes them special?' (Gills, fins, scales.)
7. 'What animal would you like to learn more about next quarter?'

slides.heading: Q2 Science Review
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this first page! It says "Q2 Science Review" and "Animal Kingdom." That means we get to be detectives and learn all about the amazing animals in our world! Let's have some fun exploring them together.

slides.setup_instructions: Shuffle the animal cards. Lay out sorting labels in a hierarchy: first vertebrate/invertebrate, then 5 class labels under vertebrate.
slides.mascot_explanation: Oh, look at all these things we need for our animal adventure! We have lots of picture cards with different animals on them, and some special labels to help us sort them. We also have some cool pictures of birds and fish to look at, and a big mat to work on. Let's ask a grown-up to help us get all these ready!

slides.text: 'The Animal Kingdom! First big question for every animal: does it have a BACKBONE? If yes, it is a ___?' 'VERTEBRATE!' 'If no?' 'INVERTEBRATE!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to ask the biggest question about animals! Does it have a backbone, like you do? If it does, we call it a vertebrate! If it doesn't have a backbone, then it's an invertebrate. We're going to be super detectives figuring this out for each animal.

slides.text: 'Name the five classes of vertebrates!' Child names them. If they forget one, give a hint: 'The ones that live in water and breathe with gills?'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is so exciting! We get to name the five special groups, or classes, that all the vertebrates belong to. Can you remember them? We have fish, amphibians, reptiles, birds, and mammals. You're doing such a great job remembering them all!

slides.text: 'Now SORT these animal cards. First: vertebrate or invertebrate. Then put the vertebrates into their five classes.' Child sorts independently.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for the super fun part! We get to take all those animal picture cards and sort them. First, we'll see if they have a backbone or not. Then, for the ones with backbones, we'll put them into their right group: fish, amphibian, reptile, bird, or mammal. You're going to be an amazing sorter!

slides.text: 'Tell me everything you know about birds!' Child shares. 'And fish!' Child shares. Check the diagrams together for any parts they forgot.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's talk about birds and fish! What makes a bird a bird? They have feathers and beaks, right? And what about fish? They have gills to breathe underwater and fins to swim! We can look at these pictures together to remember all the cool things about them.

slides.prompt: Sort all the animal cards into their correct groups. Then choose your favorite animal and draw it. Label its parts. Tell me three facts about it.
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to be artists and scientists! We're going to sort all the animals one more time to make sure we know where they go. Then, pick your favorite animal from all the cards, draw a picture of it, and tell me three cool things you know about it. You can do it!

slides.text: 'You are an animal classification expert! You can sort any animal into its group. Next quarter we will learn about amphibians, reptiles, and mammals in detail!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child correctly sort animals into vertebrate/invertebrate and then into the 5 vertebrate classes?
slides.mascot_explanation: You are such a smart animal expert now! You did an amazing job sorting all the animals into their correct groups. We learned so much about vertebrates and invertebrates, and how special birds and fish are. Next time, we'll learn even more about other animal friends!

parent_notes: Animal classification is a system that helps children organize the vast diversity of life. If the child can make the vertebrate/invertebrate distinction and name the five vertebrate classes, the Q2 science foundation is strong. Detailed knowledge of birds and fish (labeling parts, explaining adaptations) shows deeper understanding. Do not worry if some details have faded — classification is a framework that will be reinforced for years. The child's question about what they want to learn next is valuable: follow their curiosity in Q3. Some children become passionate about specific animal groups — this natural interest is the engine of Montessori learning.

title: Q2 Art Showcase — Portfolio Review and New Creation
description: The child reviews their art from the quarter (watercolors, collages, observational drawings) and creates one final piece of their choice. This celebrates creative growth and builds artistic identity.
instructions:
1. Lay out all the child's art from the quarter.
2. 'Look at all the art you created! Let us look at each piece together.'
3. For each piece: 'Tell me about this one. What do you remember about making it? What do you like about it?'
4. 'Which is your favorite? Why?'
5. 'For our last art lesson this quarter, you choose what to create: watercolor, collage, drawing, or something new!'
6. Child creates their final Q2 art piece.
7. Select pieces for the portfolio and display.

slides.heading: Q2 Art Showcase
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! It says "Q2 Art Showcase." That means we get to look at all the super-duper art you made in the last part of school and make something new and special!

slides.setup_instructions: Gather all art from the quarter and lay it out chronologically. Have all art supplies available for the child's choice creation.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, friend, we need a few things for our art party! We need all the art you made before, and all the fun art stuff like crayons, paint, and paper. We also need a special folder for your art and a place to hang up your best work.

slides.text: 'Look at ALL the art you made this quarter! Let us spread it out and look at each piece.' Lay out chronologically.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's spread out all the amazing art you made! We're going to look at each picture and painting you did, one by one. It's like a treasure hunt of all your creative fun!

slides.text: For each piece: 'Tell me about this. What were you making? What technique did you use?' Let the child narrate their artistic journey.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's talk about each picture you made. Tell me, what were you thinking when you made this one? What do you remember about painting or drawing it? I love hearing about your ideas!

slides.text: 'Which is your very favorite? Why do you love it? What makes it special?' Honor their aesthetic judgment.
slides.mascot_explanation: Out of all this beautiful art, which one is your most favorite? What do you like best about it? Sometimes it's the colors, or maybe how you drew something special.

slides.text: 'For your FINAL art piece this quarter, you choose! Watercolor? Collage? Drawing? Something totally new? It is your decision.'
slides.mascot_explanation: For your last art project this time, you get to pick! Do you want to paint with watercolors, make a cool collage, draw a picture, or maybe invent something brand new? It's all up to you!

slides.prompt: Create your final Q2 art piece using whatever materials and technique you choose. Take your time — make something you are proud of!
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, it's time to make your very own special art! You can use any colors and any materials you want. Take your time and make something that makes you feel super proud of yourself!

slides.text: Select pieces for the portfolio together. Display the child's favorite on the wall. 'You are an artist! Look at how your skills have grown this quarter.'
slides.mastery_check: Does the child show growth in technique and confidence from the beginning to end of the quarter? Can they articulate their artistic choices?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! We're going to put some of your favorite art in your special folder, and we'll hang up your best one for everyone to see. You are such a wonderful artist, and you've learned so many new things!

parent_notes: The art showcase serves multiple purposes: it develops metacognition (thinking about one's own learning), builds self-esteem (seeing growth over time), and gives the child agency in evaluating their own work. When the child narrates their art, they practice descriptive language and sequencing. Selecting pieces for a portfolio teaches curation — choosing what represents your best work. Display the child's chosen favorite prominently; this communicates that their creative expression matters. Photograph all pieces before storing or sending to family. Art development is not linear — some early pieces may look 'better' than later ones, and that is fine. Growth shows in willingness to try new techniques, sustained concentration, and personal expression.

title: Showcase Day — Demonstrating Skills for Family
description: The child demonstrates 2-3 practical life skills for a family member or friend, explaining each step as they go. Teaching others is the highest form of mastery.
instructions:
1. 'Today you get to TEACH someone else what you know! You are the teacher!'
2. Help the child choose 2-3 practical life skills to demonstrate (e.g., embroidery, making trail mix, hammering nails).
3. 'A good teacher explains each step as they do it. Practice once, then we will invite [family member].'
4. Child practices the demonstration with verbal explanations.
5. Invite the audience (parent, sibling, grandparent in person or video call).
6. Child demonstrates and explains their skills.
7. Audience applauds and asks questions. Celebrate!
materials_needed: Audience (family member, sibling, or video call participant)

slides.heading: Showcase Day
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! It's called "Showcase Day," and it means you get to be the super-duper teacher today! We're going to show off all the amazing things you've learned.

slides.setup_instructions: Help the child set up their demonstration stations. Arrange seating for the audience. Optional: set up a video call with grandparents or family.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here are the things we need for our special teaching day! You'll need the special things for the skills you choose, and someone special to watch you, like Mommy or Daddy. We can even ask Grandma to watch on the computer!

slides.text: 'You have learned so many skills! Today you are the TEACHER. Choose 2-3 things you want to show someone. What are you most proud of?'
slides.mascot_explanation: You are such a good learner, and now you get to be the teacher! Think about your favorite things you've learned to do, like maybe pouring or building. Pick two or three things you feel super good about showing off!

slides.text: 'A great teacher explains each step: WHAT you are doing and WHY. Let us practice. Show me and talk me through it.'
slides.mascot_explanation: A great teacher tells everyone what they are doing and why it's important. Let's pretend I'm your special guest right now. Show me one of your skills and tell me all about it, just like you're teaching me!

slides.text: 'Ready? Let us invite our guest! Welcome them, introduce your demonstration, and show what you can do.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, are you ready to show our real guest? Let's go get them! When they come, you can say "Hello!" and tell them what cool skills you're going to teach them today.

slides.text: Child demonstrates for the audience, explaining each step. Audience watches attentively and asks questions afterward.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to shine, teacher! You'll show your guest exactly how you do each skill, step-by-step, and tell them why you do it. They'll watch you and then ask you questions because they'll be so impressed!

slides.prompt: Demonstrate your skills! Explain each step to your audience. Answer any questions they have. Show them how much you have learned!
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the best part! You get to show off everything you know. Talk about each step as you do it, and remember to answer any questions your guest has. You'll show them how much you've learned!

slides.text: Audience applauds! 'You taught someone else — that means you REALLY know it! You should be incredibly proud of yourself.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child independently demonstrate and verbally explain 2-3 practical life skills to an audience?
slides.mascot_explanation: Hooray! Everyone is clapping for you because you did such a fantastic job teaching! When you teach someone else, it means you know it super, super well. You should feel so proud of yourself today!

parent_notes: Teaching others is the highest level of Bloom's taxonomy — it requires deep understanding. When a child can demonstrate a skill AND explain it verbally, they have truly mastered it. This showcase also builds public speaking skills, confidence, and pride. The audience should be genuine and attentive — a disinterested audience undermines the experience. Grandparents on a video call make excellent audiences because they are typically engaged and generous with praise. If possible, record the demonstration as a keepsake and portfolio piece. The child's ability to sequence steps verbally connects practical life to language development. This is a celebration of the child's growth — make it feel special.

title: Writing Practice — Pencil Writing Review
description: Review of pencil writing skills. The child practices writing letters, words, and a simple sentence. This informal assessment shows handwriting development and areas for Q3 focus.
instructions:
1. 'You have been building words with the moveable alphabet. Let us practice WRITING them with a pencil too!'
2. Start with letter formation: child writes all lowercase letters they know.
3. 'Now write some words.' Dictate 5 CVC words: cat, sun, red, hop, big.
4. 'Write a phonogram word.' Dictate: rain, tree, or moon.
5. 'Can you write a sentence? Try: The cat is big.' Child writes.
6. Observe grip, letter formation, spacing, and directionality.
7. 'Your writing has improved so much! Next quarter we will write even more.'

slides.heading: Writing Practice
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at the big words on this slide! It says "Writing Practice," and we're going to get our pencils ready to do some super writing today. It's like practicing our ABCs and making them look just right!

slides.setup_instructions: Set up writing area with good lighting. Have lined paper and a sharp pencil ready. Post the letter formation chart for reference.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's see what fun things we need for our writing adventure! We have a nice sharp pencil for making marks, some special lined paper to help us keep our writing straight, a chart with all the letters so we can see how to draw them, and a work mat to keep our space tidy. Ask your grown-up to help you gather everything!

slides.text: 'The moveable alphabet lets you write with your fingers. But you are also learning to write with a pencil! Let us practice today.'
slides.mascot_explanation: You know how we use those letter tiles to make words? Well, today we get to use a pencil to write those words down, like a real author! It's going to be so much fun to see our words appear on the paper.

slides.text: 'Write all the lowercase letters you know. Start with a, b, c... Use the chart if you need a reminder of how to form a letter.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's show off all the cool lowercase letters you know! Look at the chart if you need a little hint on how to draw them perfectly, like a little 'a' or a tall 'b'. Just do your best to write each one you remember.

slides.text: 'Now write these words as I say them: cat... sun... red... hop... big.' Speak clearly. Give time between words.
slides.mascot_explanation: Time to write some words! I'm going to say some words, and you write them down with your pencil. We'll start with "cat," then "sun," then "red," "hop," and "big." Listen carefully and write them as best you can!

slides.text: 'Try a phonogram word: RAIN. R-AI-N. The ai says /ay/. Now write a sentence: THE CAT IS BIG.' Guide spacing between words.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's try a slightly trickier word: "RAIN." Listen for the sounds and write it down. Then, we'll write a whole sentence: "THE CAT IS BIG." Remember to leave a little space between each word so we can read them easily.

slides.prompt: Write your own sentence! It can be about anything. Sound out the words and write them. Leave spaces between words. Remember capital letter at the start and period at the end.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the super writer! You can write a sentence about anything you like, maybe your favorite toy or a yummy snack. Just try your best to sound out the words and write them down, remembering to start with a big letter and end with a little dot.

slides.text: 'Look at your writing! You wrote letters, words, AND sentences. Every time you practice, your writing gets stronger. Keep writing!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child form most lowercase letters, write CVC words from dictation, and attempt a simple sentence with appropriate spacing?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay! Look at all the amazing writing you did! You wrote letters, words, and even whole sentences all by yourself. Every time we practice writing, it gets a little bit easier and a lot more fun. You are such a super writer!

parent_notes: Handwriting develops more slowly than reading in most children, and this is normal. The child may read at a much higher level than they write — the moveable alphabet bridges this gap by allowing written expression without pencil control. During this assessment, observe: Is the pencil grip correct (tripod)? Are letters formed from top to bottom? Is there spacing between words? Are letters sitting on the line? Do not expect perfection — look for PROGRESS from the beginning of the quarter. If the child reverses some letters (b/d, p/q), this is developmentally normal at this age and will self-correct with maturity and practice. Praise effort and specific improvements: 'Your s looks much smoother now!'

title: Q2 Math Review — Skip Counting and Number Patterns
description: Review of counting skills: skip counting by 2s, 5s, and 10s, counting to 100, and identifying number patterns. These foundational skills support all the operations work of the quarter.
instructions:
1. 'Let us warm up our counting brains! Count to 100 by 1s.' Time how fast (fun, not stressful).
2. 'Skip count by 2s: 2, 4, 6, 8...' Go to 20 or beyond.
3. 'Skip count by 5s: 5, 10, 15, 20...' Go to 50 or beyond.
4. 'Skip count by 10s: 10, 20, 30...' Go to 100.
5. Pattern hunt on the hundred board: 'Color all the numbers you say when counting by 2s. What pattern do you see?'
6. 'Color the 5s in a different color. And the 10s!'
7. 'Patterns are everywhere in math! These patterns will help you multiply easily.'

slides.heading: Q2 Math Review
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this slide! It's all about numbers and how we can count them in fun ways. We're going to be number explorers today and learn some super cool counting tricks!

items: Colored pencils or chips in 3 colors
slides.setup_instructions: Print a hundred board for marking. Set out colored pencils. Have bead chains available if you have them.
slides.mascot_explanation: Oh, these are the special tools we need for our math adventure! We have a big board with lots of numbers, and some colorful pencils to mark them. We'll use these to see the cool patterns numbers make!

slides.text: 'Counting is the foundation of all math! Let us see how well you count. Ready? Count to 100!' Celebrate speed and accuracy.
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to warm up our counting muscles! Let's count all the way to 100, one number at a time. Ready? Let's count together, nice and loud!

slides.text: 'Now skip count by 2s: 2, 4, 6, 8, 10... Keep going!' As the child counts, they mark each number on the hundred board with one color.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for a super fun way to count! We're going to hop over numbers, counting by twos. It's like taking big jumps: 2, 4, 6, 8... and we'll mark each number we say with a special color!

slides.text: 'Skip count by 5s: 5, 10, 15, 20...' Mark with a second color. 'Skip count by 10s: 10, 20, 30...' Mark with a third color.
slides.mascot_explanation: We're going to do more fun counting hops! First, we'll count by fives, like 5, 10, 15, and mark them with another color. Then, we'll count by tens, like 10, 20, 30, and mark those with a third color!

slides.text: 'Look at the hundred board! The 2s make a pattern — every other number. The 5s are in two columns. The 10s are all in one column! PATTERNS!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at our number board now! See how the numbers we colored for counting by twos make a neat pattern? And the numbers for fives and tens make their own special patterns too! Math is full of surprises!

slides.prompt: Study the patterns on your hundred board. What else do you notice? Can you skip count BACKWARDS by 10s from 100? Try: 100, 90, 80, 70...
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's look closely at all the colorful patterns we made. Can you see how the numbers are lined up? Now, let's try counting backward by tens, starting from 100. It's like going down the stairs!

slides.text: 'Skip counting is the secret behind multiplication! 5 taken 3 times is the same as counting by 5s three times: 5, 10, 15. You already know multiplication!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child skip count by 2s to 20, by 5s to 50, and by 10s to 100? Can they identify visual patterns on the hundred board?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such an amazing job with skip counting and finding patterns! Those patterns are like secret codes that help us understand bigger math, like multiplication. You're becoming a math superstar!

parent_notes: Skip counting and pattern recognition are foundational skills that support multiplication, division, and algebraic thinking. The hundred board makes these patterns visible: counting by 2s highlights every other number (all even numbers), counting by 5s creates two vertical columns (5s and 0s), and counting by 10s creates one column. These visual patterns stick in memory far better than rote chanting. Connecting skip counting to multiplication is powerful: 'You said 5, 10, 15 — that is 5 taken 3 times = 15!' The child may not fully grasp this connection yet, but planting the seed now means it will click naturally later. If the child can count backwards (100, 90, 80...), that is excellent preparation for subtraction.

title: Q2 Cultural Review — Community Helpers and Grace and Courtesy
description: Review of Q2 cultural studies: community helpers (firefighters, doctors, builders) and grace and courtesy skills (telephone manners, table setting, greetings). Role play reinforces social skills.
instructions:
1. 'This quarter we met many community helpers. Can you name them?'
2. Firefighters, doctors, nurses, builders, construction workers. 'What does each one do?'
3. 'We also practiced being polite and kind. Let us review!'
4. Role play: answering the telephone. 'Hello, this is the ___ home. May I help you?'
5. Role play: setting the table. Child sets a place setting from memory.
6. Role play: greeting a guest at the door. Child welcomes parent at door.
7. 'Which community helper would YOU like to be when you grow up?'

slides.heading: Q2 Cultural Review
slides.subheading: Community Helpers and Grace and Courtesy
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this! We're going to do a fun review of all the cool things we learned in our culture class. We're going to think about all the helpers in our town and how to be super polite!

slides.setup_instructions: Lay out community helper pictures. Have the toy phone and table setting items ready for role play.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these fun things we get to play with today! We have pictures of our community helpers, a pretend phone for talking, and everything we need to set a pretty table. Let's ask a grown-up to help us get these ready for our games!

slides.text: 'This quarter we learned about people who help our community. Who were they?' Child names community helpers they remember.
slides.mascot_explanation: Remember all those amazing people who help us? Like the brave firefighters or the kind doctors? Let's see if you can remember who they are and tell me all about them!

slides.text: 'Tell me about each one — what do they do? What tools do they use?' Child describes: firefighters, doctors/nurses, builders.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, tell me, what does a firefighter do with their hose? And what about a doctor? What special tools do they use to help people feel all better?

slides.text: 'We also practiced grace and courtesy! Show me how you answer the telephone.' Child demonstrates polite phone answer.
slides.mascot_explanation: You are so good at being polite! Let's practice how we answer the phone. Remember to say "Hello!" and ask nicely if you can help.

slides.text: 'Can you set a place at the table from MEMORY? Fork on the left, knife on the right, napkin, glass...' Child sets the table.
slides.mascot_explanation: Can you show me how to set the table all by yourself, just like we practiced? Remember where the fork and knife go, and the cup for your drink!

slides.prompt: Role play: greet me at the door like a guest. Welcome me, take my coat, and show me to a beautifully set table. Then call someone on the phone to invite them to dinner!
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's pretend! I'm coming to visit, and you can be the best host ever! Welcome me, help me with my coat, show me the pretty table, and then call a friend to invite them over for dinner!

slides.text: 'You know about community helpers AND you are a gracious host! These social skills will serve you your entire life.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name Q2 community helpers and their roles, and demonstrate telephone manners, table setting, and greeting?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a wonderful job today! You remembered all about our community helpers and were so good at being polite and welcoming. Being kind and helpful is super important, and you're already a pro!

parent_notes: Cultural review combines content knowledge (community helpers) with social skills (grace and courtesy) — both are essential aspects of Montessori education. The role plays make this review active and engaging rather than a verbal quiz. The child may have internalized some skills to the point where they do them automatically (greeting guests, for example), which is the goal. Others may still need prompting — note these for continued practice. The question 'What do you want to be when you grow up?' is developmentally appropriate and reveals the child's current interests and identifications. Do not push toward any answer — every interest is valid. Some children change their answer weekly; this is normal and healthy.

title: Read-Aloud: Leo the Late Bloomer by Robert Kraus
description: A gentle story about a young tiger who cannot read, write, draw, or eat neatly — until one day, in his own time, he blooms. A reassuring message about individual development timelines.
instructions:
1. Show the cover. 'This is Leo. He is a tiger who is having a hard time. He cannot do what the other animals do — yet.'
2. Read aloud. Note the father's worry and the mother's patience.
3. 'Leo's mother says: he is just a late bloomer. What does that mean?'
4. Discuss: 'A late bloomer is someone who learns things in their own time. Some flowers bloom in spring, some in summer — all are beautiful.'
5. When Leo blooms: 'He can do everything! He just needed more time.'
6. Connect: 'Is there anything you used to struggle with that is easier now?'
7. 'You are blooming every day, in your own wonderful way.'
materials_needed: Leo the Late Bloomer by Robert Kraus, illustrated by Jose Aruego

slides.heading: Read-Aloud
slides.subheading: Leo the Late Bloomer by Robert Kraus
slides.mascot_explanation: Look! This is the cover of our special book today. It's about a little tiger named Leo, and we're going to read his story together.

slides.setup_instructions: Have the book ready. This is a short but meaningful book.
slides.mascot_explanation: We need our book, "Leo the Late Bloomer," and some crayons or markers so we can draw! Ask your grown-up to get them ready for us to use.

slides.text: 'Leo is a tiger. He cannot read or write or draw or even eat neatly. His father worries. But his mother says something wise...'
slides.mascot_explanation: This part of the story tells us that Leo the tiger is having a little trouble. He can't do all the things the other animals can do yet, and his daddy is a little worried.

slides.text: Read aloud. Emphasize the mother's response: 'A watched bloomer does not bloom.' Leo's father keeps checking, but Leo blooms in his own time.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, we're going to read the story! Listen carefully to what Leo's mommy says about him needing time, just like a flower.

slides.text: When Leo blooms: 'One day Leo could read! And write! And draw! And eat neatly! He bloomed!' Joy in Leo's voice: 'I made it!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow! Look at Leo now! He learned how to do all those things, and he's so happy because he bloomed!

slides.prompt: Draw yourself 'blooming' — show something you can do now that you could not do before this quarter. Write a caption if you can!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to show us how *you* bloom! Draw a picture of something new you can do now that you couldn't do before. Maybe you can write your name or draw a super cool dinosaur!

slides.text: 'Everyone blooms in their own time. Some things come quickly, some take longer. The important thing is to keep trying and be patient with yourself.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain what 'late bloomer' means and identify areas of their own growth?
slides.mascot_explanation: Remember, everyone learns new things at their own special time, just like Leo and the flowers. You are growing and learning every single day, and that's wonderful!

parent_notes: Leo the Late Bloomer is a gift to both children and parents. It reminds us that development is not a race. Children learn to read at different ages, develop fine motor skills at different rates, and master social skills on individual timelines — all within the range of normal. The mother's patience ('A watched bloomer does not bloom') is wisdom for every homeschool parent: trust the process, prepare the environment, and avoid hovering. This book is especially meaningful at the end of a quarter when you might be tempted to compare your child to benchmarks. Instead, celebrate the unique blooming that has happened. The child's 'blooming' drawing is a powerful self-reflection tool — save it in the portfolio.

title: Sensorial Challenge — Mystery Bag with Geometric Solids
description: The child uses only their sense of touch (stereognostic sense) to identify geometric solids inside a mystery bag. This culminating activity tests and celebrates their sensorial development.
instructions:
1. 'Today we play the mystery bag game with geometric solids!'
2. Place all 5 geometric solids in a cloth bag.
3. 'Put your hand in the bag. Feel one solid. Do NOT look! Can you name it just by touch?'
4. Child reaches in, feels the solid, and names it: 'I think it is the... cylinder!'
5. Pull it out to check. Celebrate correct identifications.
6. If incorrect: 'Close! Feel the difference — this one has a point on top, so it is a cone.' Return and try again.
7. Play until all 5 are correctly identified. Then add more objects to increase difficulty.
materials_needed: Geometric solids (sphere, cube, cylinder, cone, pyramid)

slides.heading: Sensorial Challenge
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this fun game we're going to play today! It's called a "Sensorial Challenge," and it's all about using our super-smart hands to guess what's inside a special bag. We're going to be detectives with our fingers!

slides.setup_instructions: Place all 5 geometric solids in the bag without the child seeing. Have the solids' names ready for reference.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here are the special things we need for our game! We have some cool shapes, like a ball and a box, and a magic bag that we can't see inside. You'll need to ask a grown-up to help you get these shapes and put them in the bag for us to play with.

slides.text: 'Your hands know more than you think! Today we see if your hands can recognize shapes WITHOUT your eyes. This is called the STEREOGNOSTIC sense.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Today, we're going to play a game where your hands are the stars! We'll close our eyes or not look, and your hands will feel the shapes in the bag. It's like your hands have tiny eyes that can see the shapes all by themselves!

slides.text: 'I put five shapes in this bag. Reach in, feel one — do NOT look! — and tell me what it is. Use everything you know: flat faces? Curved? Pointy?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's try it! Reach your hand into the bag, but don't peek, okay? Feel one of the shapes with your fingers. Does it feel round like a ball, or does it have edges and corners? Tell me what you think it is!

slides.text: Child reaches in and feels. 'Take your time. Roll it in your fingers. Does it have flat parts? Edges? A point?' Child names the solid.
slides.mascot_explanation: Take your time and feel all around the shape. Roll it in your hands and see if it's smooth or if it has any pointy parts. Feel all the sides and edges, and then tell me which shape you think your hand found inside the bag.

slides.text: Pull it out: 'YES! It IS the cylinder! Your hands knew!' Continue until all 5 are identified.
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay! You guessed it was the cylinder! Your amazing hands knew exactly what it was without even looking. Let's keep playing until we guess all five shapes, and celebrate every time your hands are right!

slides.prompt: Challenge round: I will add more objects to the bag — a ball, a block, a pencil, a coin. Can you identify EVERYTHING by touch alone? No peeking!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for a super-duper challenge! We're going to put even more fun things in the bag, like a little car and a smooth stone. Can you still guess what they are just by feeling them with your hands, without peeking at all?

slides.text: 'Your stereognostic sense is amazing! Your hands can see shapes without your eyes. This is a real superpower!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child correctly identify at least 4 out of 5 geometric solids by touch alone?
slides.mascot_explanation: You are so amazing! Your hands are like superheroes that can feel and know shapes without even seeing them. You did such a great job guessing all the shapes, and that's a really cool superpower to have!

parent_notes: The mystery bag (stereognostic activity) is one of the most memorable Montessori experiences. The child uses tactile information alone to identify objects — this develops the ability to form mental images from touch. The geometric solids are ideal because each has distinctive properties: the sphere is completely round (no flat faces), the cube has flat square faces and sharp edges, the cylinder has two flat circles and a curved surface, the cone has one flat circle and a point, and the pyramid has flat triangular faces and a point. If the child confuses the cone and pyramid, highlight the difference: the cone is smooth and curved on the sides while the pyramid has flat triangular sides. The challenge round with everyday objects extends the game and shows that this sense is useful in daily life.

title: Grammar Review — Article, Adjective, Noun and the Verb Preview
description: Review of the noun family (article, adjective, noun) grammar symbols with a sneak peek at the verb. The child marks sentences and gets excited about learning action words in Q3.
instructions:
1. 'Let us review our grammar family!' Show all three triangle symbols.
2. Child identifies: 'Small light blue = article. Medium dark blue = adjective. Large black = noun.'
3. Give 5 sentences to mark. Child places symbols independently.
4. 'You know the NOUN family. But sentences have another important word...' Write: 'The big dog RUNS.'
5. 'What does the dog DO? RUNS! That is an ACTION word — a VERB!'
6. Show the red circle symbol: 'The verb symbol is a RED CIRCLE — round like a ball rolling, always moving!'
7. 'Next quarter we will learn all about verbs!'
materials_needed: Grammar symbols (article, adjective, noun triangles + red circle for verb preview)

slides.heading: Grammar Review
slides.subheading: The Noun Family and a Verb Preview
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this slide! It says "Grammar Review," and it's showing us the "Noun Family" and giving us a little peek at "Verbs." We're going to learn about special word families today!

items: Grammar symbols: all triangles + red circle
slides.setup_instructions: Prepare sentence strips with noun family words and verbs. Have all grammar symbols ready including the red circle for the verb preview.
slides.mascot_explanation: Oh, look at all these fun things we need for our word adventure! We have some triangle shapes that are like our word helpers, and a round red circle that's a new surprise. We also have some paper strips with words on them, and paper and a pencil for drawing. Ask a grown-up to help you find these so we can play!

slides.text: 'Quiz time! Show me the article symbol. The adjective symbol. The noun symbol.' Child identifies each triangle. 'You know the whole noun family!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, time for a little game! Can you point to the triangle that's for "article" words? Good job! Now, find the one for "adjective" words. Yay! And where is the big one for "noun" words? You found them all! You know the whole noun family!

slides.text: Give sentences: 'The small bird sang.' 'A red flower grew.' 'The old tree fell.' Child marks articles, adjectives, and nouns.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to be word detectives! Look at these sentences. We need to put our special triangle shapes above the article, the adjective, and the noun in each one. You're so good at finding those words!

slides.text: 'Great marking! But there is a word in each sentence you did not mark. THE SMALL BIRD... what? SANG! What kind of word is that?'
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a great job finding the article, adjective, and noun! But look closely — there's another word in each sentence that we haven't marked yet. What is the little bird *doing* in the sentence?

slides.text: 'SANG is what the bird DID — it is an action! Action words are called VERBS. The verb symbol is a RED CIRCLE — it is round like something always rolling and moving!'
slides.mascot_explanation: That word tells us what the bird *did*! Those are called "action words," or "verbs." We have a special symbol for verbs, and it's a red circle, like a ball that's always moving!

slides.prompt: Go back and add the red circle above the verb in each sentence. Then think of 5 actions: run, jump, eat, sleep, sing. Act them out! Verbs are ACTIONS!
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's add that red circle symbol above the action word in each sentence. Now, let’s pretend to do some actions ourselves! Can you run, jump, eat, sleep, and sing like a grown-up? That's what verbs are – they are all about actions!

slides.text: 'Now you know FOUR types of words: article, adjective, noun, and verb! In Q3 we will become verb experts. For now, look for verbs everywhere — what is everyone DOING?'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child mark all noun family words correctly and identify verbs as action words?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, you learned so many new things! Now you know about articles, adjectives, nouns, and even verbs – those are the action words! We'll learn even more about verbs next time, but for now, let's look around and see what everyone is *doing*!

parent_notes: Previewing the verb at the end of Q2 creates anticipation and excitement for Q3 learning. The red circle is the Montessori symbol for the verb — red because verbs are full of energy (like a red ball bouncing), and circular because actions continue and repeat. Do not teach the verb in depth today — this is just a taste. The child should leave this lesson knowing: verbs are action words, they are represented by a red circle, and we will learn more next quarter. The physical acting out of verbs (run, jump, eat) makes the concept embodied and memorable. Children often start identifying verbs in everyday speech after this introduction: 'Mama, you are COOKING — cooking is a verb!'

title: Q2 Math Assessment — Number Knowledge and Operations
description: Informal comprehensive math assessment covering number building, place value, the four operations overview, skip counting, and fractions. This guides Q3 planning.
instructions:
1. 'Let us see all the math you know! This is not a test — it is a celebration!'
2. Number building: 'Build 2,759 with stamps.' Check accuracy.
3. Place value: 'In 2,759, what digit is in the hundreds place? How many tens?'
4. Addition: 'Add 234 + 153 with stamps.' Check process and answer.
5. Subtraction: 'Subtract 485 - 237.' Check exchange process.
6. Skip counting: 'Count by 5s to 50.'
7. Fractions: 'Show me one third. Which is bigger: 1/2 or 1/4?'
8. Record observations for Q3 planning. Celebrate everything the child knows!

slides.heading: Q2 Math Assessment
slides.mascot_explanation: Look! This slide tells us we get to have a math party today! It's not a test, it's a super fun way to show off all the amazing math things you know. We're going to have so much fun celebrating all your smarts!

slides.setup_instructions: Set up all materials. Have a record sheet ready to note observations (for parent use only).
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these cool math tools! We have stamps to build numbers, and these circles help us see parts of a whole, like a yummy pizza! We also have a special board and papers to help us. Ask your grown-up to help you get all these ready for our math adventure!

slides.text: 'Today we celebrate all the math you have learned! I will ask you to show me different things. Just do your best — there are no wrong answers.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is just the beginning of our math celebration! I'm going to ask you to show me some math things you've learned. Just do your very best, like you always do, and remember, we're just having fun and seeing all the wonderful math you can do!

slides.text: 'Build the number 2,759 with stamps.' Observe: does the child build correctly? Know place values? 'What digit is in the HUNDREDS place?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to build a super big number! See the number on the screen? We need to use our special stamps to make it look just like that. Then, we'll point to the hundreds place, like looking for a special room in a big house.

slides.text: 'Add 234 + 153.' Observe the process: does the child combine correctly? Exchange when needed? Arrive at the right answer?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, we get to do some adding! We'll take these two numbers and put them together, like sharing your toys. We'll use our stamps to help us add them up, and we'll be super careful when we carry over to the next spot.

slides.text: 'Now subtract 485 - 237.' Observe: does the child exchange correctly? Is the process smooth or hesitant?
